bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to the Provisional Governor of Cuba, February 20, 1908

div1.p: Kean cites a lack of support for sanitary measures by the Cuban authorities, and an increase in the incidence of yellow fever. He requests assignment of another medical officer to his staff.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to the Provisional Governor of Cuba, February 20, 1908
div1.opener:
PROVISIONAL GOVERNOR'S
OFFICE
21 FEB.- 1908
RECEIVED
REPUBLIC OF CUBA
-----
UNDER THE PROVISIONAL ADMINISTRATION
OF THE UNITED STATES
----
ADVISER TO THE SANITARY DEPARTMENT
OFFICE.
Havana, Cuba, Feb. 20, 1908,
The Provisional Governor,
The Palace.
Sir:-
div1.p:
I desire to ask your consideration of the following facts
with reference to the yellow fever situation in the Island.

The difficulties of the situation are discussed at some length
in my report to the Provisional Governor, in pages 455 to 459 of
his published Report, which it is hoped General Barry will read.
An additional difficulty in this work, which is not mentioned
there, is the indifference of Cubans to this disease, which they
regard as a foe to foreigners only, and their consequent and nat-
ural opposition to thorough and troublesome operations to combat
it.

This disease has appeared at nine separate points since the
first of January. In the corresponding period of last year only
one case occurred. The question of whether the disease can be
extinguished in the Island, which is of so much importance to its
material prosperity, will be decided during the next two months.
It seems obvious therefore that the Provisional Government should
make every effort at the present time, both to carry out with en-
ergy and thoroughness the special measures directed against this
disease, and to perfect the organization of the National Sanitary
Department in each municipality.

In both directions the Sanitary Department can be greatly
assisted by the services of regular Medical Officers. Of the
three Medical Officers now on duty with the Sanitary Department,
one is stationed at Santiago de Cuba, another at Cienfuegos and
the third is not available for service outside of Havana, both
because he is in charge of the Purchasing Division which is spend-
ing large sums for mules, carts, harness and other sanitary equip-
ment, and also because he has the military duty of Attending Sur-
geon in Havana.

I request therefore the detail of another Medical Officer for
duty with the National Sanitary Department. Whether this Officer
can be spared from the Army of Cuban Pacification or must be sent
from the United States is not a matter for me to decide; but it is
suggested that if the latter is necessary, an Officer be detailed
from the Army of Cuban Pacification and replaced from the United
States, in order to avoid delay.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully, J. R. Kean
Adviser to Sanitary Department.
